ygData.subject: Re: Some questions about the algorithm
ygData.msgSnippet: Pingping, Cantera currently uses the CVODE integrator, which is the C version of VODE. The unmodified CVODE code itself is in directory ext/cvode, and the C++

Pingping,

Cantera currently uses the CVODE integrator, which is the C version 
of VODE. The unmodified CVODE code itself is in directory ext/cvode, 
and the C++ wrapper for it class 'CVodeInt', declared in 
Cantera/src/CVode.h. There is also a Cantera C++ wrapper for DASPK, 
but it is not used for anything within Cantera right now.

> 
> 1: Which ODE/DAE solver (DASSC, DVODE and DASPK) was adopted by 
> cantera for the core chemical kinetical problem dy/dt=F(y,t)? In 
> which C++ file (please give the file name) the solver was called?
> 


To the best of my knowledge, Cantera and Chemkin produce virtually 
identical results for zero-D kinetics. For example, the adiabatic 
combustion example I include in the MATLAB version (that use MATLAB 
integrators rather than CVODE) produces a final temperature that 
agrees to within 0.01 K with both the value computed by SENKIN using 
the DASAC integrator, and by C++ Cantera using CVODE. The species and 
temperature profiles are in good agreement at all times. I only 
compared the results to those of a rather old version of Chemkin II, 
but I assume they are the same with Chemkin III.
  


> 2: Did you compare the results coming out from cantera with those 
> from CHEMKIN III? Or what do you think to use different ODE solvers?
> Can we expect the same y vs. t? Indeed when I used MATLAB's ODE15S 
to 
> solve the same problem shown in SENKIN as a example,(20 reaction, 9 
> species), I got silent different y vs. t?
> 
> 3: Since k=k(t,T) and T=T(t), it is difficult to solve large sparse 
> DAEs. In my own opinion, (^-^), it is not well known that CHEMKIN 
III 
> adopt the method of infinite difference to divide the time range to 
> custom designed number of small ranges and assume the same 
> temperature within one small time range and use the previous 
> calulated T to compute k in next range. So the DAEs were changed to 
> ODE and easier to be solved by DASSC. Of course, it is not a 
prefect 
> method. Can you tell us something about how to handle this kind of 
> problem?
> 
> Thank you!
> 
> Pingping
